results.content: The Chicago Bulls dominated the NBA during the 1990s, and the trio that carried them through the second part of their dynastic run was Michael Jordan, Scottie Pippen, and Dennis Rodman.Jordan and Pippen had teamed up to lead the Bulls for their first three titles, while the addition of Rodman helped rejuvenate the team to go on to win three more titles.

Think Tank

Michael Jordan, Dennis Rodman, and Scottie Pippen: Who Among the Bulls Legends
Earned the Most in Their NBA Careers?

Modified Oct 31, 2022 | 3:23 AM EDT

via Getty

CHICAGO – 1997: Michael Jordan #23, Scottie Pippen #33 and Dennis Rodman #91 of
the Chicago Bulls catch their breath during a 1997 NBA game at the United Center
in Chicago, Illinois. Mandatory Copyright Notice: Copyright 1997 NBAE (Photo by
Andrew D. Bernstein/NBAE via Getty Images)

via Getty

CHICAGO – 1997: Michael Jordan #23, Scottie Pippen #33 and Dennis Rodman #91 of
the Chicago Bulls catch their breath during a 1997 NBA game at the United Center
in Chicago, Illinois. Mandatory Copyright Notice: Copyright 1997 NBAE (Photo by
Andrew D. Bernstein/NBAE via Getty Images)

The Chicago Bulls have been around for 56 years and have won six NBA championships. They found success during the 90s when they won their six titles in the form of two historic three-peats. Michael Jordan and Scottie Pippen powered the Bulls to their first three-peat. Dennis Rodman joined the elite duo to form arguably one of the best trios of all time.

The trio of Jordan, Pippen, and Rodman helped the Bulls win another three-peat. However, all three Hall of Famers left the Bulls after winning their sixth championship in 1998.

ADVERTISEMENT

Article continues below this ad

Michael Jordan, Scottie Pippen, and Dennis Rodman were among the best players in the league during their time. They were also compensated accordingly by the teams they played across their careers. Fans have all wondered who earned the most salary among the three in their careers.

ALSO READ: At What Age Did Michael Jordan, LeBron James, and Kobe Bryant Become Billionaires?

However, when comparing their salaries over their NBA career, one has to take into consideration the duration they played in the league. Jordan retired twice before coming back to the NBA. Meanwhile, Rodman’s NBA career started at the age of 25. Pippen, however, played for 17 years.

Scottie Pippen had more career earnings than Michael Jordan and Dennis Rodman

Scottie Pippen earned a total of $109 million in the 17 seasons he played in the NBA. However, he has often been called the most underpaid player of all time, as he used to make just $2.6 million when Jordan earned more than $30 million. Most of Scottie’s career earnings came late in his career when he joined the Houston Rockets before playing in Portland and then joining the Bulls once again.

via Getty

Michael Jordan and Scottie Pippen take down Dennis Rodman during the Bulls-Lakers matchup in December 1996 | Vincent Laforet/AFP via Getty Images

Michael Jordan is now a billionaire and is the richest athlete in the world. However, most of his earnings came from his endorsements and investments off the court. He raked in $93.7 million from salaries in his 16-year playing career. However, he made just over a million in the two seasons he played for the Washington Wizards.

Michael Jordan Tops All-Time Athlete Earnings List of a Billionaires Dozen https://t.co/EmgrV0vzJv pic.twitter.com/IsFEUKwgCA

— Sportico (@Sportico) November 4, 2021

Expand Tweet



Dennis Rodman played for some of the biggest NBA teams during his time. He started his career with the Detroit ‘Bad Boyy’ Pistons, before joining the San Antonio Spurs. He then joined the Chicago Bulls in 1995 and won a three-peat with them. Rodman had a career spanning 14 years. During his time in the NBA, the five-time champion made $27 million in salaries, which is the lowest among the three.

ADVERTISEMENT

Article continues below this ad

Michael Jordan, Scottie Pippen, and Dennis Rodman’s net worths compared

Jordan gained his billionaire status back in 2014. According to CelebrityNetWorth, MJ’s net worth is around $2.2 billion.

WATCH THIS STORY: Michael Jordan and Charlotte Hornets, LeBron James and Liverpool FC, & Other NBA Players Who Own a Stake in Sports Franchises

ADVERTISEMENT

Article continues below this ad

Scottie Pippen’s net worth is around $20 million, which is arguably very low when compared to Jordan’s. Dennis Rodman, meanwhile, has a net worth of around only $500,000 now, due to personal troubles in recent years.

What do you think of the salary and net worth comparison between the former Bulls trio? Let us know in the comment section below.

results.title: Pippen on the Bulls signing Rodman after he tried to injure him ...
results.content: The Pistons, led by gutty stars Isiah Thomas, Bill Laimbeer, and Rodman, were the Bulls' Achilles heel in the late '80s.They knocked out Michael Jordan and Pippen from the playoffs three years in a row (1988, 1989, 1990) using their infamous "Jordan Rules" — a defensive strategy designed to beat up, double-team, and frustrate Jordan at every turn.

results.title: How the Dennis Rodman trade helped the Chicago Bulls
results.content: Rodman averaged 5.2 points, 15.3 rebounds and 2.8 assists in 34.6 minutes over 199 regular season games with the Bulls from 1996 to 1998. He won three rebounding titles and even averaged a career
results.raw_content:
How the Dennis Rodman trade helped the Chicago Bulls

Stephen Beslic | Apr 9, 2023

Before the start of the 1995-96 season, the Chicago Bulls traded backup center Will Perdue to the San Antonio Spurs for Dennis Rodman, who was then a two-time NBA champion, four-time NBA rebounding champion, and two-time NBA Defensive Player of the Year.

At the time of the trade, Rodman was considered highly talented, but also extremely controversial. Rodman clashed with coaches, teammates, and the media during his time in San Antonio, so the Spurs were eager to move on from him despite his impressive rebounding abilities.

Improving frontcourt defense

The Bulls saw an opportunity to add an excellent defender and rebounder to their already talented roster. Rodmanâs presence helped the Bulls improve their frontcourt defense which gave them a better chance of winning another NBA championship.

Bulls general manager Jerry Krause and head coach Phil Jackson talked a lot with Rodman before trading for him. According to Jackson, Krause left the decision to acquire Rodman up to him. Jordan and Pippen approved the move.

âPhil and I talked very carefully about this,â Krause said. âWe did an awful lot of homework and found out a lot of things. We were both satisfied.â

The Rodman effect

The Bulls were hurting on the boards since losing Horace Grant to free agency in 1994, and Jordanâs return forced Toni Kukoc to play out of position at power forward.

The 1995-96 campaign was the final year of Rodmanâs contract, and he exceeded expectations, averaging 5.5 points, 2.5 assists and a league-best 14.9 rebounds in 32.6 minutes over 64 games in the regular season while behaving well. The Bulls decided to extend his contract for two more years.

âThe one promise we made to Dennis, was, we said at the beginning, when we first talked, we said at the end of the year we will sit down and weâll talk about the future, and I think thatâs what we are gonna do, we are going to sit down at the end of the year,â Krause told Jim Gray from NBC Sports before the Bulls played the Magic in the 1996 Eastern Conference Finals.

âDennis has been outstanding, he hasnât missed a practice, he hasnât been late, heâs done the things weâve asked him to do on the basketball court, heâs a tremendous practice player, Dennis has been very good for this team and I believe that heâs a good person.â

Rodman averaged 5.2 points, 15.3 rebounds and 2.8 assists in 34.6 minutes over 199 regular season games with the Bulls from 1996 to 1998. He won three rebounding titles and even averaged a career-high 3.1 assists in 1997.

The five-time NBA champion averaged 5.4 points, 11.3 rebounds and 1.8 assists in 32.4 minutes over 58 playoff games with the Bulls.

In the end, the trade worked out well for the Bulls and the Spurs. Rodman thrived in Chicago, playing a crucial role in helping the Bulls win three NBA championships in a row from 1996 to 1998.

Perdue, on the other hand, played a solid role for the Spurs as a backup center, and they went on to win their first NBA championship in 1999.

Stephen Beslic is a writer on Sports Illustrated's FanNation Network. Stephen played basketball from the age of 10 and graduated from Faculty of Economic and Business in Zagreb, Croatia, majoring in Marketing.
